p: The fecal–oral route is the main means of direct transmission of PEDV via the feces and/or vomitus of infected pigs ( Jung and Saif, 2015). Indirect contact transmission of PEDV is also frequent within and between farms, particularly, with a low biosecurity, via other contaminated fomites including ( Jung and Saif, 2015; Kim et al., 2017b): transport trailers ( Lowe et al., 2014), farm workers’ hands, boots and clothes ( Kim et al., 2017b), feed ( Bowman et al., 2015a; Dee et al., 2014; Schumacher et al., 2017), feed ingredients and additives, such as spray-dried porcine plasma ( Pasick et al., 2014; Perri et al., 2018), and feed totes used for transporting bulk feed or feed ingredients ( Anon., 2015; Scott et al., 2016). PEDV remained infectious on tote material for 35 days at room temperature ( Scott et al., 2016). PEDV cross-contamination also occurred during feed manufacturing ( Schumacher et al., 2018).
